where_to_read:
Locked in a metal tube and cart service
                 stopped

reviews.review_text: I LOVE the look of it and think it is a fine gift for a NYC dweller, Like DEVIL IN THE WHITE CITY for anytone  who lives i Chicago.... I also love the 4 page negative Amazon review, in addition.
It's cartoons! I sent it back

This book is graphically interesting but the narrative is abbreviated to the point of seeming like a fever dream. Imagine taking The Power Broker and dropping 49 pages out of every 50 and you'll have some idea of what is left here.
Excellent graphic presentation of a planning legend.
Condition of book was far worse than expected

These authors know very little about Robert Moses! There are many factual errors, there are innuendos and outright falsehoods printed in this book and there seems to be an almost total lack of historicity. Actually, I'm not sure that the author, in particular, has any right to make the claims that he does. I would be interested in what impelled him to write this book as his background seems so poorly suited to this kind of research!!

I was a bit disappointed by this. I liked the art (although I'll admit, I wanted more pictures of his projects, and the abstract style sometimes took away from truly envisioning what he was going for).  The writing was a touch off.  Overall, I think it works as a primer, but wouldn't recommend this to someone really trying to learn about Moses.

title: Robert Moses: The Master Builder of New York City
word_cloud: comic love look think fine gift dweller anyone live also love page negative review addition cartoon send back graphically interesting narrative abbreviate point seem fever dream take drop page idea leave excellent graphic presentation planning legend condition far worse expected author know little many factual error innuendos outright falsehood print seem almost total lack historicity sure author particular right make claim impelled write background seem poorly suit kind research entertaining bite disappointed like art admit want picture project abstract style sometimes take truly envision go write touch overall think work primer someone really try learn moses
summary:
THE NEW YORK TIMES BESTSELLER!

From the subway to the skyscraper, from Manhattan's financial district to the Long Island suburbs, every inch of New York tells the story of one man's mind: Robert Moses, the architect who designed it all. Now, in Pierre Christin and Olivier Balez's new graphic biography, the rest of Robert's story will be told.
story_arc:
Bad luck, followed by promise, ending in a
                    final fall
